III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section • (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
Description child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An initial service plan was not filed within 30 days of the youth
being removed nor provided to the parents.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 6/23/2025, via telephone.
Complainant reported the initial service plan (ISP) was not
completed for Youth A and Youth B within 30 days per
requirement nor was a copy provided to the parents. Complainant
reported the first service plan sent to the courts was emailed on
4/10/2025, and it was labeled an updated service plan (USP) and
covered the period of 10/30/2024 – 1/27/2025. Complainant
reported this report was not accepted and sent back to the agency
for corrections as it had many issues. She reported the agency
reported to her they had some redaction issues. Complainant
reported communication went back and forth between her and the
agency regarding the ISP. Complainant reported even if the report
was considered an ISP, though it was not laced as such, it was
not submitted until 4/10/2025, and the time period covered was
listed as 10/30/2024 – 1/27/2025. Complainant reported this
report was accepted but she still wanted a copy of the initial
service plan and questioned whether the ISP report was
completed by the agency. Complainant stated Birth Father and
Birth Mother did not get a copy of the ISP report from the agency.
District Manager (DM) was interviewed on 8/5/2025, via TEAM.
He reported he was supervising this case with Foster Care Worker
1 when the case was placed with the agency. He reported the
ISP was completed timely and it was dated 9/30/2024 –
10/29/2024 but submitted on 11/1/2024, and it was two days late
in the MiSACWIS system. He reported the agency could not
generate the report as it had a computer glitch of not generating
the social work contacts. He reported upon getting the report
generated, the report had to be redacted for the courts. DM
reported redactions are completed outside of MiSACWIS and a
helpdesk ticket would not be needed, however, it was a process
and time consuming to print the report, redact the report and put
2

the report back into the MiSACWIS system. He reported the
report was not able to be generated until 11/1/2024.
DM reported there were other issues with the report being sent
and received by the court and all parties correctly due to redaction
issues and using the wrong court mailbox. He reported he
submitted the report to the court, but the court sent it back
because the courts wanted the agency to obtain the parents’
signatures. DM reported after obtaining Birth Father and Birth
Mother signatures on the report, the report was sent to the correct
court inbox, however, all attorneys involved reported they did not
receive the reports (ISP and court report). DM reported to make
sure all reports were delivered to the right mailbox, Foster Care
Worker 1 took the reports to court to make sure the reports were
delivered to the right mailbox. DM reported Birth Father and Birth
Mother were provided the ISP and Parent Agency Treatment Plan
on 11/26/2024, and the court and all attorneys received the
reports on 12/5/2024. DM reported Birth Father And Birth Mother
participated in the service plans for Youth A and Youth B.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed on 8/5/2025,
via TEAM. She reported she was the assigned supervisor on
Youth A and Youth B’s case from when they were placed until
present. She reported she signed off on all of Youth A and Youth
B’s service plans and reported all reports were approved and
completed timely. She reported the system was not generating
social work contacts or allowing the agency to redact the reports.
Foster Care Worker 1 was not interviewed for this investigation
as she no longer works for the agency. No known contact
information was available.
Birth Father and Birth Mother were interviewed jointly on
8/20/2025, via telephone. Birth Father and Birth Mother reported
they participated in Youth A and Youth B’s treatment plans and
Foster Care Worker 1 explained and discussed the treatment
plans with them. Birth Father and Birth Mother reported they were
given copies of the treatment plans in November of 2024. Birth
Father and Birth Mother reported they had no issues with the
agency providing them information on Youth A and Youth B.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A case record: Placed three times, one placement
with a relative and two with licensed/unrelated foster
homes. His current placement is dated 11/22/2024 to
present. Youth A’s first placement began on 9/30/2024.
3

• Youth B case record: placed three times in
licensed/unrelated foster homes. He is placed with his
sibling. Youth B’s first placement began on 9/30/2024.
• Initial Service Plan dated 9/30/2024 – 10/30/24 and
submitted on 11/01/2024.
• Social Work Contact documented there was an issue
generating the report. The date was 10/30/2024 and there
was a note that stated, “Batch Job 178 -complete _ social
work contact_CM40. The report was not able to be
generated until 11/1/2024.
Analysis Upon review of documentation, interviews, social work contact,
and Case service plan there is insufficient evidence to support a
rule violation. ISP was completed timely and Birth Father and
Birth Mother reported they participated in the ISP service plans
and received copies of the plan.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
Section • (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
Description child and parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An updated service plan was not filed within 90 days of the youth
being removed nor provided to the parents. The parents have not
been provided a USP every 90 days.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed on 6/23/2025, via telephone.
Complainant reported USP’s are due every ninety days after the
first 120 days that children are placed into foster care.
Complainant reported Birth Father and Birth Mother have not
received USP’s every ninety days. She reported the USP dated
1/20/2025 – 4/24/2025 was successfully sent to the court on
6/11/2025. This report was missing redactions and was late.
District Manager (DM) was interviewed on 8/5/2025, via TEAM.
DM reported that the USP’s following the ISP were completed
timely and involved Birth Father and Birth Mother. He reported
the agency had some issues with the redaction process and would
not allow the agency to redact the report. He reported this issue
occurred off and on from 10/30/2024 until 1/24/2025. DM reported
all of the reports were approved in MiSACWIS timely per
4

requirement and were not late. He said the issue was generating
social work contacts and redacting the report. He reported due to
the computer glitch, the reports were not submitted to the courts
until the reports were redacted and included the social work
contacts. DM reported the USP from 10/30/2024 -1/27/2025 was
sent to the court and all attorneys on 4/10/2025. USP dated
1/28/2025 – 4/24/2025 was sent to the court and all attorneys on
6/11/2025.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was interviewed on 8/5/2025,
via TEAM. She reported she was the assigned supervisor on
Youth A and Youth B’s case from when they were placed until
present. She reported she signed off on all of Youth A and Youth
B’s service plans and reported all reports were approved and
completed timely. She reported the system was not generating
social work contacts therefore the reports could not be printed to
allow the agency to redact the reports and put it back into the
MiSACWIS system. She confirmed this occurred from 10/30/2024
until 1/24/2025. FCS reported the agency was not going to send
the reports to the courts to have the courts reject the reports due
to not being redacted or missing social work contacts.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed on 8/5/2025, via
telephone. She reported she was assigned the case on
4/25/2025 until present. She reported that Birth Father and Birth
Mother are involved in Youth A and Youth B’s treatment plans.
She reported when she visits their home, she explains the service
plan and Parent Agency Treatment plan to them and they ask
questions, sign the reports and a copy of the report is left with
Birth Mother and Birth Father.
Birth Father and Birth Mother were interviewed jointly on
8/20/2025, via telephone. They reported they are always
provided a copy of the reports (USP’s) and treatment plans. They
reported they have no issues of receiving reports and they are
active participants. Birth Father and Birth Mother reported they
receive USP’s on a regular basis and when reports are due.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• USP’s in MiSACWIS dated 10/30/2024 -1/27/2025,
1/28/2025 – 4/24/2025, and 4/25/2025 – 7/23/2025 were all
approved timely.
• Social Work Contact dated 10/30/2024 -1/27/2025, were all
documented in MiSACWIS as “Batch Job 178 _ complete
social work contact _ CM 40.”
5

Analysis There are no CPA rules surrounding submitting reports to the
court. Based on documentation and interviews, there is no
evidence to support USP’s were late and not provided to Birth
Father and Birth Mother every 90 days. Birth Father and Birth
Mother reported they receive their children’s service plans and
had no issues and the USP’s were submitted timely as required
per the rule.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
